partintro.para: Part I of the DAC Developer's Guide contains an architectural overview of the Dataphor Data Access Components.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Components are classes that do not manifest themselves on a user interface (non-visual), but instead perform "internal" behavior for the application. Controls are are classes that are usually presented on the user interface of the application (visual). When designing and application, both components and controls can be visually prepared and manipulated from within the Visual Studio .NET designer. The Dataphor Data Access Components (DAC) is a set of components and Windows Forms controls that provide interactive access to data housed in a database system.

The .NET Framework (and therefore Visual Studio .NET) includes a data access paradigm called ADO.NET. The Dataphor Data Access Components provide a complete alternative to ADO.NET, with some distinct advantages. Some benefits of the DAC are most apparent when compared with ADO.NET, while others are distinct for the industry.

sect1.title: DAC versus ADO.NETDifferences From ADO.NET
sect1.para:
ADO.NET and the DAC are fundamentally different in the way that they buffer and navigate the data. ADO.NET requires the developer to determine an adequate subset of data to retrieve from the DBMS into a buffer. The developer then performs interaction and manipulation within the absolutely indexed buffers. Then the developer determines how to appropriately post updates to the DBMS. ADO.NET does not abstract or insulate the data source's query language or capabilities. The DAC on the other hand performs the data querying, buffering, and reconciliation automatically. Navigation in the DAC is performed as relative positioning within what logically appears to be the entire dataset. These differences are so fundamental that the DAC concepts could not be built on top of ADO.NET without severely compromising the desired architecture. Here are a few comparisons between ADO.NET and the Dataphor DAC:
ADO.NETDAC
Each different DBMS is queried using a different query dialect. Application logic must be re-created for each DBMS.Accepts a single query dialect then emits whatever dialect is necessary to the backend DBMS.
The developer must formulate queries that retrieve only a "reasonable" amount of data.The DAC handles the end query formulation and automatically ensures appropriate quantities are fetched.
Controls are "loosly" bound to the dataset buffer through property binding.Controls are made intrinsically data aware.
Reconciliation is facilitated manually by formulating parameterized update statements.The DAC automatically manages buffer reconciliation including transactional implications.
Control data binding is based (by default) on control containership.Controls are data bound independent from their containers.
Most data behavior only takes place at run-time.Datasets can be activated and viewed both at run-time and design-time.

sect1.title: DAC BenefitsBenefits
sect1.para:
There are many benefits to using the DAC including:
Intrinsically data aware controls can react intelligently to focus changes, dataset states, and formatting.
Controls are bound to datasets indirectly through DataSource instances. This allows for existing forms to be easily attached to different datasets regardless of control containership.
Controls report the number of rows that each requires, so the dataset buffer size is dynamic (based on demand).
The DataView (dataset buffer) automatically retrieves data into the buffer and updates the DBMS from the buffer.
Data aware user interfaces can be configured and activated at design time within the Visual Studio .NET environment.
Controls and data components can be visually connected and configured so very little coding is required to build data aware applications.

listitem.para: Single query dialect - The DAC can be attached one of a variety of data sources, yet queries are formulated in a single dialect and translated realtime into the appropriate dialect for the data source. This allows for applications to be easily ported from one database backend to another.
Query processor - If a particular data source does not support certain functionality (i.e. scalar or relational operators) the DAC will automatically pick up the query processing.

Updatable queries - Regardless of the expression used by the dataset, the data can be updated. This is especially useful in the case of joins and unions where views of that nature would not ordinarily be updatable against the DBMS.
Navigational access - Dataset query is logically formulated for the entire set of data. The DAC will automatically rewrite the query underneith and fetch subsets of data.

Incremental search - Users can perform on-the-fly "find nearest" type queries of even the largest underlying tables. As part of the navigation access, the DAC will automatically re-query and fetch appropriately to make such access effecient and tranparent.

Application transactions - Manipulations to complex data relationship automatically participate in optimisticly concurrent transactions so changes are all committed or rolled back when a "master" dataset's change is accepted or rejected respectively.

chapter.title: DAC InstallationInstallation
chapter.para: InstallationThe Data Access Components are relatively easy to install. For application design they can be installed into the Visual Studio .NET's "toolbox". For runtime deployment, the DAC assemblies can be copied into an application's local folder, or they can be installed into the Global Assembly Cache (GAC). For more general information on these concepts, see the MSDN documentation for the .NET Framework.

sect1.title: DAC Standard SetupStandard Setup
sect1.para: To install the Data Access Components, run the setup.exe program and follow the instructions.

The standard DAC setup performs the following:
Copies the DAC Assemblies (DLLs) to the directory you chose during the install.
Installs the DAC Assemblies into the GAC.
Registers the Assemblies in the GAC with Visual Studio so that they appear in the Form Designer ToolBox.
Copies the documentation help files and the readme.rfd.
Creates links on start menu for docs and readme
Generates a GAC.licence file and places it in CommonAppDataPath directory (which in this case is Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\Alphora\Dataphor.)
Copies DAERegisteredAssemblies.config, an Assembly Map that contains Assembly Aliases for use in D4 code, to the Version Specifice CommonAppDataPath directory (which in this case is Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data\Alphora\Dataphor\VersionNumber.)
Creates registry key to instll path for use by other programs. This is not used by the DAC components directly.

The components can also be installed on a machine manually via the Deployment and then installed manually on the Visual Studio toolbox. The assemblies must be placed into the GAC to be used from within Visual Studio .NET.

sect1.title: DAC DeploymentDeployment
sect1.para:
DeploymentWhen deploying the programs you have created which use the DAC, the following steps need to be done.
The DAC DLLs must be installed. They can be place in the program directory or they can be installed into the GAC.
The GAC.license file must be copied the the CommonAppDataPath of the DAC, the same directory it was installed to originally.
The Assembly map (DAERegisteredAssemblies.config) must be installed into the Version Specific CommonAppDataPath of the DAC, the same directory it was installed to originally.

chapter.title: DataSession Components
chapter.para: DataSessionThe DataSession components represents a logical connection with a data source. There are different DataSessionBase descendant components for each backend data source, each prefixed with the name of the DBMS. To establish DAC data source connectivity place the appropriate DataSession component into the designer from the Visual Studio .NET toolbox (e.g. DB2DataSession for IBM DB2). To establish a connection to an instance of the Dataphor DAE, use a DataSession component.

Typically an application will only need one DataSession instance. This instance should be configured and created at application startup so that the DataSession instance is available for data connectivity from the various forms of the application.

sect1.title: Device-specific DataSession PropertiesDevice-specific DataSession Properties
sect1.para: Each specific DataSessionBase descendant has it's own set of unique properties. The properties allow device specific settings to be configured, such as connectivity information. See the reference part for information about each specific DataSessionBase descendant's properties.

sect1.title: DataSession PropertiesDataSession Properties
sect1.para:
To configure a DataSession component, configure the SessionInfo and the SessionName properties. The SessionInfo contains settings and configuration parameters such as UserID and Password. See reference information for the
SessionInfo class for details.
Setting the SessionName property registers the DataSession with a static "global" list of application DataSessions so that DataViews can be connected without being on the same design surface.

sect1.title: Activating the DataSessionActivating the DataSession
sect1.para: Activating the DataSession is done by setting the Active property to True or calling the Open method at runtime. Activating the DataSession causes it to establish a connection with the underlying data source. If a connection cannot be made, and appropriate exception will be thrown.

chapter.title: DataView ComponentDataView Component
chapter.para: DataViewThe DataView component represents a dataset within a data source, based on a specific query expression. The DataView forms the core data manipulation component around which the other components in the DAC revolve. Through the DataView, data can be searched, retrieved, and modified. The DataView performs all data buffering transparently as navigation/searching occur.

sect1.title: Connecting to the DataSessionConnecting to the DataSession
sect1.para: The DataView established connectivity with the underlying data source through a DataSession instance. The DataView is associated with a DataSession instance through the Session property. If the DataSession associated with the DataView is not active when the DataView is activated, it will be activated at that time (if possible).

The Session property can be set directly, or it can be set indirectly through the SessionName property. The SessionName property makes it easy to link the DataView to DataSession instances that are located elsewhere in the application.

sect1.title: Setting the ExpressionSetting the Expression
sect1.para: The DataView uses a query expression to retrieve it's logical dataset. The expression is given in terms of a D4 or RealSQL expression which returns a relation (table result). The query does not need to restrict the dataset beyond what is logically desired, because the DataView will only retrieve the sets of information that are necessary to populate it's internal buffers.

The query dialect (D4 or RealSQL) used for the expression depends on the Language property setting of the DataView, not the Language property of the SessionInfo structure of the associated DataSession instance. See the D4 or RealSQL reference for details on each language.

sect1.title: Column AdornmentsColumn Adornments
sect1.para:
The Columns collection property of the DataView allows the specification of additional per-column definitions such as defaults and constraints. Each column "adornment" is an instance of the AdornColumnExpression class. The AdornColumnExpression has the following "interesting" properties:
PropertyDescription
ColumnNameSpecifies the name of the column for which this adornment applies.
DefaultSpecifies the default value for the specified column of a newly inserted row.
ConstraintsContains a collection of ConstraintDefinition classes specifying the list of constraints applicable to this column. A ConstraintDefinition class has an ExpressionString property containing a valid D4 expression that evaluates to True if the value satisfies the constraint, False otherwise. Within the constraint expression, the value of the column is represented by an instrinsic variable called "value".
MetaDataMetaData is extra information about the column that might be useful to the application. This is a list of arbitrary identifier/string values.

sect1.title: Row ConstraintsRow Constraints
sect1.para: Row-level constraints can be specified through the DataView's Constraints collection property. Like column level constraints, the row level constraints are manifest as a collection of ConstraintDefinition instances. Each ConstraintDefinition instance contains a D4 expression that returns True if the constraint is satisfied. For row level constraint expressions, the column values are accessible by their names.

sect1.title: Setting the OrderSetting the Order
sect1.para: Before the DataView can be activated, a sort order must be established for the dataset. The order is set through the OrderString property of the DataView. The order string takes the following form: order {<ne column name comma list>}For example: order {LastName, FirstName}
It should be noted that not only does the sort order affect the logical ordering of the data, but incremental searching is also tied to the sort order.

sect1.title: Activating the DataViewActivating the DataView
sect1.para: The DataView is activated by setting the Active property to True, or calling Open at runtime.

sect1.title: Data Manipulation StatesData Manipulation States
sect1.para:
At any given moment, a DataView is in one of the following states:
StateDescription
InactiveThe DataView is not active. In this state, data navigation and manipulation operations fail.
BrowseThe DataView is active and is in a navagable state. Data can be read, but not modified.
InsertThe DataView is active and is positioned on an inserted (but not yet posted) row of data. The DataView is placed into Insert state by a call to the Insert or Append method, or by a call to Edit when there are no rows in the dataset.
EditThe DataView is active and the row buffer at the current positioned can be edited. The DataView is placed into Edit state by a call to the Edit method.
The state of a DataView can be determined by examining the State property.

The state of the DataView is changed by activating, deactivating, or by calling one of the state changing methods. The following methods affect the state of the DataView:
MethodDescription
EditPlaces the DataView into Edit state, or does nothing if the DataView is already in that state. If the DataView is empty (0 rows), Edit causes the DataView to go into Insert state.
InsertPlaces the DataView into Insert state. The temporary row buffer will appear at the position previously occupied by the active row.
AppendPlaces the DataView into Insert state. The temporary row buffer will appear after the last row in the dataset.
CancelCancels any changed made to the data buffered by insert or edit and returns the DataView to the Browse state. If the DataView is already in Browse state, Cancel does nothing.
PostAccepts any changes made to the data buffered by insert or edit and returns the DataView to the Browse state. If the DataView is already in Browse state, Post does nothing.

sect1.title: Master/Detail LinkingMaster/Detail Linking
sect1.para: DataView instances can be linked in such a way that one instance presents a restriction (or detail) of information from another. This is informally referred to as master/detail linking, where the "detail" is the DataView being restricted and the "master" is the DataView from which the restriction information is coming. As the master DataView is modified or navigated, the detail DataView will reflect the new restriction criteria.

Master/detail linking helps to automate data manipulation tasks involving tables involved in a one-to-many relationship. For example, if we have a Customer table and a CustomerPhone table and we allow there to be many CustomerPhone rows for each Customer row, we may wish to present a user interface that shows the list of CustomerPhone rows under the current Customer we have selected. This would be accomplished by performing a master/detail link between the DataView representing the CustomerPhone table and the DataView representing the Customer.

Master/detail links are accomplished by setting the MasterSource property of the detail DataView to a DataSource instance that is attached to the master DataView. Additionally, the MasterColumnNames and DetailColumnNames are set to represent the column or columns that are to be used to join the tables.

A master table must be active, have at least one row, and have values for the columns that constitute the MasterColumnNames in order for the detail DataView to be in a Valid state. If an active detail DataView not in a Valid state, it will behave similarly to when it is not Active. If a change occurs to the master DataView which makes the detail DataView valid, the detail DataView will automatically act normally for an Active DataView. To determine if a detail DataView is in an invalid state, call the IsValid method.
When a detail table row buffer is inserted, the linked detail table's columns are automatically defaulted to values from the appropriate columns of the master table's active row.

sect1.title: Filtering DataFiltering Data
sect1.para: Arbitrary filter conditions can be specified for a DataView by setting the Filter property to a valid restriction ("where clause") expression. If this value is changed while the DataView is active, the DataView will automatically requery underneath to reflect the change.

sect1.title: NavigationNavigation
sect1.para: At any given moment, the DataView represents a single "active" row position within the logical dataset specified by the Expression. Navigating the active row in the DataView takes place in a relative manner not based on an absolutely indexed position. In other words, the DataView can be navigated to the beginning of the set, forwards by a specific number of rows, or even to memorized bookmarks, but there is no concept of row (or record) numbers. The ordering of the rows being navigated is based on the sort order of the DataView.

There are two indicators, BOF and EOF, that indicate when the DataView is at the beginning or end of the logical dataset respectively. When initially opened, the BOF property of the DataView will always be True. The EOF property will return True after navigating past the last row of the dataset (not when navigating to the last row). EOF will only be True upon activation of the DataView if the dataset is empty. Just like EOF, once the DataView has been navigated past the first row, the BOF indicator will not be True until navigating before the first row.

The following methods can be used to perform basic DataView navigation:
MethodDescription
FirstNavigates the active row to the first row of the logical dataset. After this method is called, the BOF property will return True.
PriorNavigates the active row to the row immediately prior to currently active row, or, if the DataView is already situated on the first row, sets the BOF indicator.
NextNavigates the active row to the row immediately following to currently active row, or, if the DataView is already situated on the last row, sets the EOF indicator.
LastNavigates the active row to the last row of the logical dataset. After this method is called, the EOF property will return True.
MoveByNavigates the active row a specific number of rows away from the currently active row, or, sets the BOF or EOF indicator appropriately.

sect1.title: BookmarksBookmarks
sect1.para: Bookmarks are used to memorize and recall specific active row positions in the DataView. A bookmark is retrieved by getting the Bookmark property; the position is restored by setting the same.

sect1.title: SearchingSearching
sect1.para: A DataView can be searched and navigated to specific rows. This type of searching does not restrict the logical dataset like the Filter or Expression does, this search is navigational. Navigational searching takes place on the columns specified in the sort order of the DataView.

Navigational searching is performed using the FindKey and FindNearest methods of the DataView. FindKey either locates the row by the given criteria and returns True, or performs no navigation and returns False. FindNearest positions the active row on the row of the dataset that most closely matches the given criteria. FindNearest is particularly useful for allowing the user to perform "incremental search" behavior.

sect1.title: Accessing Data ProgrammaticallyAccessing Data Programmatically
sect1.para: Access to the data in the active row buffer can obtained through the Fields collection of the DataView. Specific Field class instances are retrieved from the Fields collection either by their column name or their ordinal position in the collection. The Fields collection can be enumerated and also contains the standard collection properties such as Count.

sect1.title: Field ClassField Class
sect1.para: The Field class contains the logic necessary to get and set data values for individual columns within the active row. It also provides information about the represented columns data type. Field instances are obtained from the Fields collection of the DataView.

Field data is typically read and written to using the AsXXX properties (where XXX is the data type). Columns within a newly inserted row will not have values yet, and attempting to read the field value will throw an exception. To determine if a Field has a value, use the HasValue property. If the DataView associated with the Field instance is not already in an editing state (Edit or Insert) when a Field value is changed, than the DataView will automatically be placed in an editable state.

chapter.title: DataSource ComponentDataSource Component
chapter.para: DataSourceThe DataSource components provides a level of indirection between the DataView Component and the data-aware controls. The decisions regarding which controls are associated with what logical datasets is usually made when controls are placed on the form, but the actual association of a dataset with the form may not occur until runtime. The DataSource allows for forms to be easily "hooked up" to a DataView without connecting each control individually.

sect1.title: Attaching to the DataViewAttaching to the DataView
sect1.para: The DataSource is associated with a single DataView instance through the View property. Any controls that are associated with the DataSource instance are then indirectly associated with the DataView instance.

sect1.title: Using the DataSource at RuntimeUsing the DataSource at Runtime
sect1.para: DataSource instances are often associated with DataView instances at run time. This allows multiple forms to be attached to the same logical dataset at runtime. For example, if there is a "browse" form shown for the Customer table and the user selects "Edit..." to modify the currently select Customer row: the edit form's controls could be easily associated with the existing DataView instance on the browse form by attaching the DataSource instance on the edit form to the DataView instance on the browse form.

chapter.title: DBGrid ControlDBGrid Control
chapter.para: The DBGrid control visually represents data within the DataView in a tabular fashion. The DBGrid not only displays the currently active row of the DataView, but also as many other rows above or below the active row as space allows. The DBGrid also provides mechanisms to navigate the DataView. The DBGrid is a read-only control with the exception of boolean columns which can be represented with toggleable check boxes embedded on the DBGrid.

sect1.title: AppearanceAppearance
sect1.para: The DBGrid draws a table of rows representing a subset (not necessarily proper) of the DataView's dataset. The first row of the DBGrid table is always the "header" containing the names of the columns whose values are represented below. If the DBGrid is unable to display all columns in the allotted space, it displays a horizontal scroll bar. A vertical scroll bar is presented for row navigation within the dataset.

sect1.title: Attaching the Grid to the DataSourceAttaching the Grid to the DataSource
sect1.para: The DBGrid, like other data aware DAC controls, is associated with a DataSource instance through the Source property. When the DBGrid is linked to a DataSource instance what is in turn linked to an active DataView instance, the DBGrid automatically becomes "live" with data (whether in the Visual Studio .NET designer or at runtime).

sect1.title: Setting the Grid ColumnsSetting the Grid Columns
sect1.para: When attached to a live dataset, the DBGrid component displays the columns of information specified by the Columns collection property, and in the order they appear in that collection. If no columns are explicitly given when the DBGrid instance becomes active, the Columns collection is automatically populated with default values from the DataView's data type information.

The GridColumn class represents an individual column in the Columns collection. The GridColumn class has several properties including the following:
PropertyDescription
ColumnNameName of the data column in the DataView to present. This does not have to be unique across the collection, or in other words, the same data column can be displayed multiple times.
WidthWidth in pixels of the presented data column.
TitleThe text displayed in the header row for the column.
TextAlignThe horizontal alignment of data text displayed for the column of data.
ColorBackground color for data column.
VisibleWhether or not the data column is currently visible.

The GridColumn can also be descended from to provide unique functionality. One such descendant is the CheckBoxGridColumn that renders a check box control instead of the textual representation of the data. The CheckBoxGridColumn can be configured as read-only through the ReadOnly property.

sect1.title: NavigationNavigation
sect1.para:
In addition to visual navigation capabilities, the DBGrid has extensive keyboard support. The following is a partial list of supported hotkeys:
KeyDescription
LeftScrolls to show the column just prior to the leftmost visible column.
RightScrolls so that the second-to-leftmost column becomes the leftmost column.
Ctrl-LeftScrolls so that the leftmost column becomes the rightmost one.
Ctrl-RightScrolls so that the rightmost column becomes the leftmost one.
Ctrl-Alt-LeftScrolls so that the first column is the leftmost column.
Ctrl-Alt-RightScrolls so that the last column is the leftmost column.
Up, DownNavigates to the prior or next row.
PgUp, PgDnNavigates to the prior or next page of rows.
Home, EndNavigates to the topmost or bottommost visible row in the grid.
Ctrl-Home, Ctrl-EndNavigates to the first or last row in the dataset.

chapter.title: Incremenatal Search ControlIncremental Search Control
chapter.para: The IncrementalSearch control facilitaties "find nearest" style navigational searching of the DataView. The IncrementalSearch control searches within one or more columns that make up the DataView's sort order. As the sort order of the DataView changes, the available search criteria also changes.

sect1.title: AppearanceAppearance
sect1.para:
There are several properties of the IncrementalSearch control that effect it's appearance:
PropertyDescription
TitleVSpacingThe space between the criteria controls and the vertically alligned titles.
TopMarginThe space between the top of the control and the criteria controls.
NoValueBackColorThe color used for criteria with no value (to differentiate between a blank value and no value).
InvalidValueBackColorThe color used for criteria to indicate that the search criteria is invalid.
TitleAlignmentThe relative alignment of the criteria titles.

sect1.title: Search DelaySearch Delay
sect1.para: The IncrementalSearch control delays searching until a specified amount of time after the most recent keypress has occurred. This interval ensures that searching does not occur while the user is actively typing search criteria. The delay interval is configurable by setting the TimerInterval property to the number of desired milliseconds.

sect1.title: Incremental Search ColumnsIncremental Search Columns
sect1.para: When the DataView is activated, or the sort order changes, the IncrementalSearch control prepares search criteria for the columns of the sort order. The display information for the search criteria is automatically deduced from the DataView's column definitions or it can be specified through the Columns collection property. The Columns collection contains instances of the IncrementalSearchColumn class. It should be emphasized that the list of Columns does not specify the search criteria for the IncrementalSearch control; the search criteria is always tied to the sort order of the DataView. The IncrementalSearchControl instances merely specify formatting information for columns that may appear as search criteria.

The IncrementalSearchControl contains the following properties:
PropertyDescription
ColumnNameThe associated column name.
TitleThe text to use for the title of the search criteria.
TextAlignThe alignment of text within the search criteria editor.
ControlWidthThe pixel width to use for the search criteria sub-control.

sect1.title: Order LookupOrder Lookup
sect1.para: The IncrementalSearch control contains a lookup "button" to allow the user to change search criteria. The behavior of this button must be specified by the control user and does nothing by default. To define specific behavior for this button, attach an event to the OnOrderLookup event.

chapter.title: Column-Level ControlsColumn-Level Controls
chapter.para: Besides the DBGrid control, the other controls in the DAC are column-level, in that they display the value of an individual column within the active row of the DataView. Many of the DAC controls are data-aware extensions of the regular Windows Forms controls included with the .NET Framework.

sect1.title: Attaching Data Aware Controls to the DataSourceAttaching Data Aware Controls to the DataSource
sect1.para: Each column-level control not only has a Source property to associate the control with a DataSource instance, but also a ColumnName property to designate the associated column.

sect1.title: Static TextStatic Text
sect1.para: The DBText control displays the value of the column within the active row as static (non-editable) text. DBText inherits the properties of the Label control, including the ability to align the text through the TextAlign property.

sect1.title: TextBox-style ControlsTextBox-style Controls
sect1.para: There are several controls that display information and allow the editing of data in a text box. Each text box control allows the user to uniquely edit data value as text. When focus leaves the control or when an explicit update request is made from the DataView, the text box controls update the field values of the DataView. The simplest such control is the DBTextBox control which descends from the standard TextBox control. The DBIntegerTextBox control is similar to the DBTextBox control except that it only accepts integer values. The DBDateTextBox is another DBTextBoxBase descendant control that facilitates editing dates.

sect1.title: Lookup ControlsLookup Controls
sect1.para: There are a few controls that appear similar to a TextBox, but also provide an elipsis button to allow the user to "look up" a value for the column. When the lookup button is triggered, the OnLookup event is raised.

The DBLookupTextBox control can encapsulate a user specified control so long as it descends from DBTextBoxBase. By default, the DBLookupTextBox encapsulates a DBTextBox control. The encapsulated control class is specified through the TextBoxClassName property. The DBDateLookup control is like a DBLookupTextBox except that it houses a DBDateTextBox (by default) and provides a calendar lookup.
The DBIntegerScrollBox control also encapsulates a control, but assumes that the edited value is integral and provides up and down scrolling buttons and a scrolling slider to alter the value.

The DBLookupButton control provides an elipsis button for use in looking up values that cannot be edited directly (like they can be with the DBLookupTextBox). If the AutoNextControl property is True then focus is advanced to the next control after the lookup takes place.

sect1.title: Radio GroupRadio Group
sect1.para:
The DBRadioGroup provides a group box containing radio button from which the user can choose the value for the data column. The following properties are some that can be used to configure the behavior of the DBRadioGroup:
PropertyDescription
ItemsThe list of items to show as radio buttons.
ValuesThe associated data values for each of the radio buttons.
ReadOnlyWhen True, the control cannot be used to modify the data value.
EnabledWhen False, the control cannot be focused or the data modified.

sect1.title: CheckBoxCheckBox
sect1.para: The DBCheckBox control facilitates the editing of boolean data values. It's behavior is similar to the standard CheckBox control. The DBCheckBox features an AutoUpdate property that specifies whether changing the control's state in turn immediately updates the data value, or whether updating is deferred until the control loses focus. If AutoUpdate is False, changes made to the DBCheckBox's state will be posted when the control loses focus or when the DataView explicitly requests an update. If the DBCheckBox's state is updated and AutoUpdate is True, the changed state is posted after a possible delay (as specified by the AutoUpdateInterval property).

sect1.title: ImageImage
sect1.para: The DBImageAspect control displays an image from the database while maintaining that image's aspect ratio. A new image value can be set by the user through the clipboard keyboard shortcuts (Ctrl-V for paste) or programmaticly through the Image property.

sect1.title: Tree ViewTree View
sect1.para:
The DBTreeView control shows data in a hierarchical manner. The following properties are available to configure the DBTreeView:
PropertyDescription
LookupKeyColumnNamesMust be set to a key (column list string) that that identifies a node in the tree.
LookupParentKeyColumnNamesMust be set to a key that corresponds with a node's parent identity.
AutoRefreshIf True, the DBTreeView rebuilds itself when the data changes.

chapter.title: Non Data-Aware ControlsNon Data-Aware Controls
chapter.para: Although the Dataphor DAC are certainly focused on providing complete and elegant data access and manipulation capabilites, there are also several controls that are not directly data aware. Some of these non data aware controls are in place to provide a base for a data aware counterpart.

sect1.title: ImageImage
sect1.para: The ImageAspect control displays an image similarly to the standard Image control features certain "stretching" and display capabilities. The ImageAspect control has a StretchStyle property that controls how the image is resized to fit the control's dimensions. A useful StretchStyle value is StretchRatio which sizes the image to use the largest amount of space while maintaining image's aspect ratio. The Center property specifies whether a displayed images is centered within any unused space available within the control.

sect1.title: LookupPanelLookup Panel
sect1.para: The LookupPanel is a control container which includes an elipsis button to allow the user to "look up" a valuepresumably for the controls contained within the LookupPanel. The actual lookup behavior is determined by the developer by attaching a handler to the OnLookup event. This control is particularly useful for creating lookups for values of a compound key (key with more than one column). Keystokes made to controls placed in and isntance of the LookupPanel are intercepted by the LookupPanel and made to invoke the lookup. In this way, the LookupPanel makes child controls read-only except that they invoke a lookup.

sect1.title: RadioButtonGroupRadio Button Group
sect1.para:
The RadioButtonGroup control provides a group of radio box controls, each representing a specific data value. The following properties affect the behavior of the RadioButtonGroup:
PropertyDescription
ItemsUsed to determine what radio button options are available within the group.
CheckAlignSpecifies the position of the radio button sub-controls (left, center, or right).
AppearanceSpecifies whether or not the radio buttons show up as standard buttons or radio buttons.
MarginWidthThe width of the margin between the control's inside boundary and the sub-controls.
ButtonFlatStyleConfigures the "flat style" of the radio buttons (see the RadioButton class)
TextAlignSpecifies the alignment of the text protion of the radio buttons.
SelectedIndexThe index of the currently selected radio button.
ColumnsThe number of columns by which to align the radio buttons.

sect1.title: ToolBarToolBar
sect1.para: The ToolBar and ToolBarButton controls provide simple horizontally or vertically aligned tool bar support. The ToolBar container will accept any control as a child and will align it's child controls in a line (and to fit the "bar"). The ToolBar button is similar to a standard Button except that it does not accept focus.

chapter.title: DataLink
chapter.para: DataLinkThe DataLink control is the class used by the DAC to enable controls to become data aware. The DataLink provides a connection to the DataView, specifies the buffering requrements of the control (or other DataLink consumer), and provides event sinks necessary to respond to the DataView's data and state changes. It should be noted that although DataLinks are typically used for making controls data aware, the DataLink does not necessarily have to be hosted by a control. For example, the DataView itself uses a DataLink internally to connect to a master DataView.

sect1.title: Preparing the DataLinkPreparing the DataLink
sect1.para:
The following actions may be taken to prepare a DataLink:
Create an instance of a DataLink class. This is usually done in the constructor of the control.
Set the Source property. The Source is usually configured as a pass through property of the control (i.e. the control has a Source property that gets and sets it's value from the DataLink instance's Source property.
Set the BufferCount property. This property is set to the number of rows that are concurrently accessed. For a grid-type control, this is the number of rows that are currently visible in the grid. For controls that only access the values of the currently active row this should be left to one (1). This property should also be maintained (if necessary) as the requirement for the number of buffered rows changes.

sect1.title: Accessing DataAccessing Data
sect1.para: The DataLink consumer may access the data of the active row of the DataView instance by directly reading values from the DataView's Fields collection. A reference the the DataView instance can be obtained from the View property of the DataLink. To determine if the DataView instance is obtainable and active, use the DataLink's Active property.

A DataLink consumer that requires access to more than one row of the DataView can access the Buffer property. It is important that if the DataLink consumer requires access to more than one row, it sets the BufferCount appropriately. When accessing the Buffer, the first buffer visible to the current DataLink is determined by reading the FirstOffset property of the DataLink. The currently active row of the DataView instance can be determined by accessing the ActiveOffset property. The Buffer is a list of ViewRow instances from which Row instances can be obtained. From a Row instance a Scalar value can be obtained. From a Scalar value, a Conveyor can be used to get the value in terms of a .NET data type. Alphora.Dataphor.DAE.Runtime.Data.Scalar LScalar = Link.Buffer[RowIndex].Row[ColumnIndex]; Text = LScalar.DisplayConveyor.GetAsString(LScalar);See the Dataphor DAE Developer's Guide for more details.

sect1.title: Responding to DataLink EventsResponding to DataLink Events
sect1.para:
The DataLink receives notification when the state or data of the DataView changes. These events can be noticed by descending from the DataLink class and overriding certain methods or by hooking event handlers to certain events. The following is a list of events that are available through the DataLink.
MethodEventDescription
UpdateRowOnUpdateRowInvoked when the link should apply and changes that have not yet been posted to the active row. Update row is most commonly invoked before the DataView posts the data row to the dataset. Controls such as the DBTextBox allow changes to be made that aren't immediately saved to the DataView. This event indicates that such controls should immediately save such changes.
RowChangedOnRowChangedInvoked when the active row has changes as a result of data edits (as opposed to scrolling, activation, etc.)
DataChangedOnDateChangedInvoked when the active row has changed as a result of anything other than data edits.
FocusControlOnFocusControlInvoked when a validation error has occurred and a control associated with the error should be focused. The culprit field is passed as an argument.
StateChangedOnStateChangedInvoked when the DataView changes edit states.
ActiveChangedOnActiveChangedInvoked when the DataView goes between the active and inactive states. This and the StateChanged events are also invoked in simulation, such as when the links between this DataLink instance and the DataView instance are changed (i.e. the DataSource instance is attached to another view).

sect1.title: FieldDataLinkField Data Link
sect1.para: The FieldDataLink class descends from DataLink and provides features that are helpful when implementing controls that are associated with a particular column of the dataset.

The constructor for the FieldDataLink takes a control instance reference to be associated with the link. The control associated with the FieldDataLink is obtainable through the Control property. The control will automatically be focused when a FocusControl event occurs.

The FieldDataLink has a ColumnName property that, like the Source property, is typically used in a pass-through fashion by the control. If any change occurs that may affect the specific column specified by ColumnName, a FieldChanged (and therefore OnFieldChanged) invocation occurs.

The FieldDataLink also has a ReadOnly property that allows the data link to operate in read only mode. If the state of the ReadOnly property changes, the UpdateReadOnly virtual method is invoked, which in turn invokes the OnUpdateReadOnly event.

The FieldDataLink has a Modified property that can be used to trach whether or not the link has pending updates to be made. To indicated that a change has been made, call the Edit method which will set the modified flag as well an ensure that the DataView is in an editable state. To undo the modified state, call Reset which clears the modified flag an re-reads the links value from the DataView.
